data.title: Alaska
data.description: This gin cocktail, made with Yellow Chartreuse and orange bitters, “dances between spirit-driven and citrus-forward,” according to Keli Rivers of San Francisco’s Whitechapel. “It’s good, moving from one side of the spectrum to the other.”

list.step: Add all of the ingredients to a mixing glass with ice, and stir until chilled.
Strain into a chilled coupe glass.
Express the oil of a lemon peel over the drink, and garnish with that lemon peel.

data.title: Bamboo
data.description: Sherry cocktails are getting a lot of love from the bartender community, and this underrated 19th-century drink is a delicious way to go.

list.step: Add all of the ingredients in a mixing glass with cracked ice, and stir until chilled.
Strain into a chilled coupe.
Garnish with a lemon twist.

data.title: Adonis
data.description: Give this easy-drinking, low-alcohol sipper a spin. Made with equal parts sherry and vermouth, it pairs beautifully with tapas and other savoury bites.

list.step: Add all of the ingredients to a mixing glass with ice, and stir until chilled.
Pour into a coupe glass, and garnish with an orange peel.

data.title: Blood & Sand
data.description: The classic Scotch-based Blood & Sand cocktail tastes like neither. The recipe for the Blood & Sand first appeared in print in Harry Craddock’s 1930 The Savoy Cocktail Book. It’s a complex combination of fruity and smoky, and a cinch to make with just four ingredients of identical proportions.

list.step: Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.
Shake, and strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
Garnish with an orange peel.

data.title: Boulevardier
data.description: Swap out the gin in a Negroni for rye bourbon and you get the delicious Boulevardier. It’s equally complex as its gin-based predecessor, but the bourbon adds warmth, making it perfect for autumn and winter drinking.

list.step: Add all the ingredients to a rocks glass filled with ice and stir to combine.
Garnish with an orange twist.
Add both of the ingredients to a cocktail shaker and fill with ice.
Shake, and strain into an Old Fashioned glass filled with crushed ice.

data.title: Sazerac
data.description: Forget the Hurricane. The Sazerac is what you should drink in New Orleans. One of America’s earliest cocktails, the Sazerac is a homegrown New Orleans specialty. Peychaud’s bitters are a key element and were created by Antoine Peychaud, a French Quarter pharmacist, who invented the cocktail in the 1830s. The Sazerac was originally made with cognac, but an insect epidemic destroyed many French vineyards and resulted in the lasting switch to rye whiskey.

list.step: Rinse a chilled rocks glass with absinthe, discarding any excess, and set aside.
Add the rye whiskey, fill with ice and stir.
Strain into the prepared glass.
Twist a slice of lemon peel over the surface to extract the oils and then discard.

data.title: Incredible Hulk
data.description:
If you enjoy cocktail with vibrant colours, then you will love the Incredible Hulk cocktail. It has a vibrant green colour reminiscent of the skin of its namesake.

When the Hpnotiq is poured into the cognac, the drink turns green. The drink was invented at Sean Comb's restaurant, Justin's, in New York City.

Supercharge your Incredible Hulk by adding 30ml of white rum to the drink.

list.step: Fill a lowball glass with ice and add cognac.
Pour Hpnotiq over ice, and the colour will transform to green.

data.title: Hammered Hulk
data.description: This bright green cocktail is tropical and fruity but not too sweet.

list.step: Mix the vodka, rum, Midori, and laraha liqueur in shaker.
Shake.
Pour into a on the rocks glass filled with ice.
Add the carbonated water and lemon and lime soft drink.
Squeeze the lemon and lime into the drink.

data.title: Rhubarb & Custard
data.description: An elegant vodka-based drink that'll wow your guests - it's made with creamy advocaat liqueur and homemade fruit syrup.

list.step: put the caster sugar in a saucepan with 75ml water.
Heat very gently, so the sugar disappears but the water doesn’t bubble.
Tip in the chopped rhubarb, cover with a tight-fitting lid and increase the heat a little so it begins to boil.
Simmer, covered, for about 5 mins until the rhubarb is very tender but not disintegrating.
Turn off the heat, and tip the pan’s contents into a fine sieve over a bowl.
Use a wooden spoon to gently squeeze the rhubarb so that you get all the juices, but no pulp.
Tip back into the pan and boil rapidly for a few mins until just syrupy.
Pour into a jug – you should have about 125ml. Leave to cool completely.
Chill 4 cocktail glasses with ice or in your freezer. Shake the vodka and 100ml of the rhubarb syrup together with ice until mixed and chilled down.
Make small shreds of rhubarb using a vegetable peeler and place into iced water – this will make them curl up.
In a separate jug, whisk together the advocaat and lemonade with more ice to lighten. Divide the vodka and rhubarb mixture between the glasses, straining through a small sieve to catch the ice.

Carefully pour 25ml of your advocaat mixture into each glass over an upsidedown spoon (the mixture should float on the surface of the vodka syrup mixture). Drain the rhubarb shreds well and use to garnish your cocktails.

data.title: Cucumber, Mint & Melon Punch
data.description: A fruity, minty, refreshing punch for a summer party. The mix of juicy honeydew, cantaloupe and watermelon chunks make this the ultimate cooler to beat the heat.

list.notes: peeled and chopped into small chunks

list.step: Put the cucumber and half the mint in a large bowl or jug, and pour over the vodka. Cover and leave to steep for at least 24 hrs or for up to 1 week in the fridge, stirring every few days. Strain through a fine sieve.
Pour the vodka, lime juice and sugar into a larger jug.
Stir well.
Using a melon baller, scoop out as many melon balls as you can. Add them to the jug and leave to steep for 30 mins - 1 hr in the fridge.
Top up with sparkling water.
Add the remaining mint leaves just before serving with extra lime wedges.

data.title: White Sangria
data.description: Combine dry white wine, triple sec, fresh peaches and raspberries for a refreshing brunch drink.

list.notes: non-alcoholic white wine or white grape juice can be used as an alternative

list.step: In a glass pitcher, add wine and liqueur; stir to blend.
Add fruit to pitcher.
Stir gently.
Serve immediately or refrigerate until serving time.
Just before serving, stir ice cubes into pitcher. Pour into glasses to serve.

data.title: Frozen Strawberry Daiquiri
data.description: This slushy cocktail is best made when strawberries are in season and at their ripest. With just four ingredients you can whip up this thirst quencher in 10 minutes.

list.step: Blend the strawberries then push the resulting puree through a sieve to remove some of the seeds.
Tip the sieved puree into the blender again and add the ice, rum and lime juice.
Blend again and divide the mixture between 2 Martini glasses.
Thread the lime slices and strawberry halves onto the cocktail sticks and place onto the edge of the glass.

data.title: Apple Prosecco Punch
data.description: Spritz up a basic apple cocktail with a dash of Prosecco and a splash of vodka.

list.step: Pour the apple juice, vodka and lemon juice into a punch bowl and chill for 1-2 hrs.
When you’re ready to serve add the Prosecco and ice.
Garnish with apple and lemon slices.
Half fill a 2-litre pitcher witch ice.
Add the summer cup, tonic and strawberries.
Stir.
Pour.
Furnish each glass with a lemon zest and a sprinkle of pepper.
Half fill a 2-litre pitcher witch ice.
Add the blueberries, cucumber, summer cup and tonic.
Stir.
Pour into Pina Colada cocktail glasses.
Garnish with watermelon.

data.title: A Rose by Any Other Name

list.step: Half fill a 2-litre pitcher witch ice.
Add the strawberries, lemon wheels, summer cup and rose lemonade.
Stir.
Pour into rocks glasses.
Half fill a 2-litre pitcher witch ice.
Add the pomegranate, summer cup and tonic.
Stir.
Add the basil.
Stir again.
Pour into cold Collins glasses.
Add the lavender to each glass.

data.title: Courgette Martini
data.description: Courgette and martini may seem unlikely bedfellows, but blended with lemon and shots of gin and vermouth, this is a delicious take on a cocktail classic.

list.step: Mix the courgette with the lemon juice and sugar and leave to steep for 1 hour.
In the meantime, place a martini glass in the fridge to chill.
Strain the courgette mixture through a sieve into a jug.
Fill a cocktail shaker with ice then add 25ml of the courgette syrup followed by the vermouth and gin.
Stir gently a few times.
Strain into your chilled glass.
Garnish with mint.

data.title: Summer punch
data.description: A simple, refreshing drink that's perfect for a summery gathering. For an extra-special twist, swap the sparkling water for champagne.

list.step: In a bowl, mix the lemon juice and sugar until the sugar dissolves.
Transfer into a large serving bowl.
Add the other liquid ingredients, fill to the top with ice.
Stir gently.
Garnish with herbs and lemon slices.

data.title: Sloe Gin & Juniper Syrup
data.description: This autumnal hedgerow cocktail has a blend of botanical notes from the gin, infused with a juniper syrup, which makes for a sweet-sharp tipple.

list.step: Put the sugar in a small saucepan, then add 100ml water and the juniper berries.
Bring to the boil, then take off the heat and gently squash the berries in the liquid using a potato masher.
Leave to steep until completely cold.
Strain into a sterilised bottle or jar. Will keep in the fridge for up to 2 weeks.
Put the sloe gin, lemon juice, gin and juniper syrup in a cocktail shaker with a few ice cubes.
Shake well.
Strain into a tumbler filled with crushed ice.

data.title: Salted Caramel Pecan Sour
data.description: A modern version of the classic sour cocktail, this is the ultimate Christmas drink. Salted caramel and Icelandic vodka make an irresistible mix.

list.step: Toast the pecans in a dry saucepan for 1-2 mins, then take off the heat.
Quickly add the sugar and 80ml water, stir rapidly to dissolve the sugar, add the salt, then leave the mixture to cool completely.
Pour through a sieve to remove the pecans.
Pour the pecan salted caramel syrup, vodka, egg whites, clementine juice and bitters into a cocktail shaker.
Shake hard for 30 secs to add volume to the egg white.
Add some ice and shake again for a further 15 seconds.
Strain into rocks or coupe glasses.
Garnish each with a dehydrated orange slice and grate fresh nutmeg over, to taste.

data.title: Blood Orange & Star Anise Fizz
data.description: The perfect zesty tipple for a spring celebration. Who could resist a blend of sharp blood orange, star anise and orange liqueur, topped with bubbles?

list.step: Soak the blood oranges (skin on) in 100ml orange liqueur for 3 hrs.

Heat oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6 and tip the oranges, along with the soaking liquid, into a small roasting tin or ovenproof dish. Roast in the oven with the star anise for 30-40 mins or until the orange skins start to caramelise. Remove the skins and star anise, and purée the pulp in a food processor until smooth. Strain through a fine mesh sieve and chill until needed.
Mix 25ml of the purée with 1 tsp each of tequila and orange liqueur per cocktail, and top with Prosecco.

data.title: Martini
data.description: Undoubtedly the most famous of gin cocktails, the Martini reserves an unrivalled place at the summit of any cocktail book and is the true test of any bartender’s skills. It’s also the cocktail that generates the most arguments and the “perfect” Martini is an accomplishment so rare to behold, it’s akin to the Holy Grail.

list.step: Pour gin and dry vermouth in cocktail shaker with ice.
Stir well.
Strain into chilled Martini glass.
Zest the lemon peel and garnish by twisting it in a perfect spiral.

data.title: Lemon Fizz Gin Punch
data.description:
Delivering a zesty citrus path, making a drink that’s bittersweet and refreshing, yet foolishly boozy. Ultimately summery and disgracefully indulgent, this is one that’ll lead you down the garden path and into an evening of raucous hedonism.

This is great for sharing from a large punch bowl.

Needless to say, this one needs a little bit of forward planning. You’ll want to make and cool the honey water ahead of time, and the tea.

list.notes: Plonk a tea bag in the bottle an hour before use

list.step: Add a couple of pint glasses worth of ice to a punch bowl.
Add the gin, lemon juice and honey water.
Stir well until combined.
Top up with the Prosecco and lemon tonic.
Stir lightly.
Garnish with orange wheels.

data.title: Singapore Sling
data.description: The Singapore Sling was the go to cocktail for ladies at the start of the 20th Century. The drink is a leggy, vibrant-pink damsel with a fruity taste and a mid-summer vibe. Garnish with just a cherry for that high-society vibe, or tone down the fancy-pants look with a cocktail umbrella and a sparkly straw. Your drink, your call.

list.step: Add all ingredients and ice into a cocktail shaker.
Shake.
Strain into a Hurricane glass
Top up with sparkling water.
Garnish with slice of orange and a cherry.

data.title: Pegu Club
data.description:
If cocktails could grow on trees, then the Pegu Club would almost certainly have been harvested in a citrus grove. This classic is a tart, mouth-watering affair that offers a surprising complexity due to the bitters bestowed upon it.

It’s a drink well suited to a fine line in time – the tipping point between day and night, when everything starts to get just a little more uptempo, but not quite rowdy just yet.

list.step: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with half a cup of ice.
Shake until cold.
Pour into a chilled Martini glass.
Garnish with a slice of lime.
Top tip; If you find the above recipe a little to tart, add a dash of sugar syrup into the mix before shaking.

data.title: Ramos Gin Fizz
data.description:
New Orleans serves as a beacon of light to cocktail fans, home as it is to so many great drinks. While the Hurricane and the Sazerac are great offerings, the Ramos Gin Fizz was designed with us in mind. It’s a pretty little gin cocktail with all the creaminess of a Pina Colada and none of the coconut; only citrus, sugar and vanilla.

New Orleans is a city that opens wide and swallows its visitors whole, pulling them into a whirling jumble of music and dancing and bad behaviour. This is a cocktail to shake up when you need that sort of a holiday.

list.step: Add all ingredients, expect the sparkling water, to a cocktail shaker.
Shake hard (without ice).
Add ice and shake again.
Strain into a chilled glass.
Top up with sparkling water.
Garnish with a slice of orange.

data.title: Red Snapper
data.description:
The Red Snapper is gin’s answer to the Bloody Mary. In our opinion, it works better too – a quick-witted, articulate riposte if you will. It’s a tall, refreshing pick-me-up and a much more civilised hair of the dog remedy than the Corpse Reviver.

This is a drink that was designed with 11am on Sunday in mind, and as such has been hijacked by the brunch munching masses. Next time you feel the fatigue wrought by too much dancing, order a Red Snapper and be sure to cast aspersions at the Bloody Mary crew. Gin is pure class-in-a-glass, and so are you.

list.step: Use the salt and pepper to rim your glass (preferably a Collins).
Add the rest of the ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice.
Strain into your glass.
Add half a celery stick to garnish.

data.title: Shaky Pete’s Ginger Brew
data.description:
Shaky Pete’s Ginger Brew is a frosty, frothy beer cocktail that is almost impossible not to drink without letting out big, satisfied ‘aaaahs’ between gulps. Described by the Hawksmoor team (it’s place of birth) as a ‘turbo-shandy for the discerning drinker,’ this cocktail is boozy enough to give you a buzz, but tall enough to refresh.

This is one for the end of a long hot summer’s day. Start practising that lip-smacking, foam-moustached ‘aaaaah’ of satisfaction right away…

list.step: Whizz up the ginger syrup, lemon juice, gin and half a cup of ice in a blender.
If you don’t have a blender, place the ginger syrup, lemon juice and gin in a cocktail shaker with ice and get you shake on.
Strain through a sieve into a frozen beer stein and top up with ale.
Garnish with a slice of ginger.

data.title: Pink Gin
data.description: Pink Gin is a Royal Navy cocktail with a history dating back to the 1800s. The drink is sharp and heavy, with its alluring colour hinting at its rich, dry taste (and its somewhat dizzying effects). This is a cocktail very well suited to the end of a long day; it’s no fuss to fix up and it’ll leave you with a nice, leisurely buzz.

list.step: Combine both ingredients in a shaker with ice.
Stir.
Strain it into a glass.
Twist to lemon zest over the top to release the oils. Then discard zest.

data.title: Gimlet
data.description:
The Gimlet is a light green, lime-heavy cocktail with a rich naval history and a sharp kick. It’s origins aren’t the most glamorous – scurvy has never been sexy – but it’s long been adopted as a sipping drink by the cocktail drinking masses and is so very easyto make.

This is one for summer sipping, so grab a bottle of lime cordial (or make your own!) and your favourite gin next time you’re organising a barbecue and wait for everyone to praise you for your excellent bartending skills.

list.step: Add both ingredients to a mixing glass with ice.
Stir.
Strain into a chilled Martini glass.

data.title: English Garden
data.description:
You’ll be hard pushed to find a recipe for an English Garden cocktail that doesn’t describe it as a quintessentially British dink, and with good reason. It’s a wonderful example of the English countryside, with elderflower liqueur and fresh pressed apple juice evoking images of endless orchards and languid summer days. It makes us think of the innocence of yesteryear – of conker matches, cress boxes in windowsills and Easter egg hunts.

Cooling and refreshing, sweet and subtle, this is a cocktail that tastes exactly how you want the sound of clinking glass on a long, hot day to taste. A hint of lemon juice prevents the elderflower liqueur from making it overly sweet, whilst the apple juice brings a huge, lip-smacking freshness that’ll perk you right up.

list.step: Half fill a shaker with ice.
Add the gin, elderflower liqueur, lemon and apple juice.
Shake until combined.
Strain into an ice filled hurricane glass.
Garnish with an apple wheel and a thin twist of lemon peel.

data.title: Corpse Reviver
data.description:
The Corpse Reviver, or family thereof, (no not called Zombies, that’s a different concept altogether) is a collection of cocktails designed as a Hair of the Dog hangover cure. The drink is laden with spirits and will certainly cure you of any self-pity. For about an hour. Then it’s back to bed for you.

Best served the day after your birthday, even though you’re old enough to know better. Shame on you.

list.step: Add all ingredients into a cocktail shaker with ice.
Shake.
Strain into a Martini glass.
Garnish with a cherry.

data.title: Colonial G&T
data.description:
You’ve heard of a G&T, right? If not, stop reading and head to a bar to order one. You should probably have a stern word with your self on the way too… The G&T is Britain’s national drink; it’s a cocktail far greater than the sum of its parts, despite the fact that its individual parts are each entirely divine.

The Colonial G&T takes us right back to gin and tonic’s first date, prior to the days of carbonation, Happy Hours and swift halves. While the drink tastes like a G&T, it’s flat and short, and when served chilled in a rocks glass makes for a nice summer sipper.

list.step: Add all ingredients into a cocktail shaker.
Shake hard and fast.
Strain into a rocks glass with ice.
Garnish with slice of lemon.

data.title: Bronx
data.description: While it would be unfair to say that the Bronx is a Martini for those not yet ready to face reality, dumbed down as it is with a splash of orange, it’s not a million miles away from being a fresher, sweeter and certainly more easily imbibed version of its stately cousin. The Bronx is a lively drink too, ready and waiting to wake your mind and your mouth up ahead of a big night.

list.step: Squeeze the orange, add gin, both vermouths and half a cup of ice into a cocktail shaker.
Shake until cold.
Strain into a Martini glass.
Garnish with a twist of orange peel.

data.title: Aviation
data.description:
The Aviation is a classic cocktail that has enough charm to convert vodka sluggers into gin quaffers in the time it takes to find your seat in a 747. The drink is lent a distinctive, slight sky-blue hue by the addition of an ever-elusive liqueur – Crème de Violet – and is best drunk on a beautiful spring day, when the colour of the sky matches that of the nectar in your glass.

Be warned, this is a strong drink, so please ensure that your seat backs are up, tray tables stowed, window blinds up and seatbelts are fastened for take off.

list.step: Pour the ingredients into an ice filled cocktail shaker and shake.
Pour into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish with a cherry, a candied violet or lemon twist.

data.title: Basil Smash
data.description:
The Basil Smash is a relatively new drink (well, new in the context of cocktails) with an alluring Hulk-green tint and a real fresh kick. In fact, the addition of fresh basil means that this drink is basically a vegetable, and certainly a welcome way to get one of your five-a-day.

This is a cocktail that suits a sweltering summer day, the sort that leaves you trailing patterns into the condensation on the side of your glass and daydreaming about plunging headfirst into a cool lake.

list.step: Place basil and lemon into a cocktail shaker.
Gently muddle the lemon and basil "smashing" the ingredients.
Add simple syrup and gin and top up with ice.
Shake vigorously.
Double strain into an ice-filled rocks glass.
Garnish with basil leaves.

data.title: Bee’s Knees
data.description: The Bee’s Knees, along with the cat’s whiskers, entered the US lexicon in the 1920s. Both phrases are called into use to describe something of excellence. The Bee’s Knees, a sweet, citrus cocktail, lives up to its moniker, and will no doubt leave you buzzing too. This is one to sip when under the thrall of a dark and hazy speakeasy.

list.step: Add gin and honey to a shaker.
Stir until the honey dissolves.
Add the lemon and orange juice and top up with ice.
Shake well.
Strain into a martini glass.
Garnish with an orange zest twist.

data.title: Clover Club
data.description:
The Clover Club is a pretty-in-pink classic cocktail, with a rich, silky texture and a great complexity that is perfectly balanced to keep most parties happy.

This is a night-time drink – one to be sipped when it’s dark and calm outside but light and loud at the bar. Be warned however, the person who orders just one Clover Club is a rare beast...

list.step: "Dry shake" all ingredients in a shaker for about 30 seconds until the egg has emulsified and the berries have been pulverised.
Add half a cup of ice.
Shake again until cold.
Fine strain into a chilled coupe glass.
Garnish with a raspberries

data.title: Blueberry Spice Moscow Mule Shots
data.description: A mini Moscow Mule with a blueberry twist.

list.step: Add ingredients into a shaker.
Stir gently.
Serve between 4 shot glasses or mini copper mugs.
Garnish with 1 min leaf and 1/4 orange slice.

data.title: Holiday Spice Moscow Mule Shots
data.description: A mini Holiday Spice Moscow Mule - with a holiday flare.

list.step: Add ingredients into a shaker.
Stir gently.
Serve between 4 shot glasses or mini copper mugs.
Garnish with 1 min leaf and 1/4 orange slice.
Fill a highball glass with large ice cubes.
Add vodka and cranberry juice, then top with lemon and lime soda.
Stir.
Garnish with lime wedges.

data.title: Dirty Gold Martini
data.description: This recipe is really easy and a classic. Which makes it part of the must know cocktails. So go forth and shake up a few of your own dirty martinis in our honour.

list.step: In a shaker filled with ice add in your vodka, brine, water, and vermouth.
Shake vigorously for 30 shakes.
Strain into a chilled martini glass.
Remove the garlic from the garlic stuffed olives.
Stuff olive with blue cheese.
Garnish with three blue cheese stuffed olives on top of your martini.
Do the same as above, however, replace the water with 22ml of brine.

data.title: Elegant Spiced Pear Martini
data.description: Savour the flavour of an autumn harvest in this elegantly cool cocktail, topped with a sprinkle of nutmeg and cinnamon.

list.step: In shaker with ice, add vodka and pear nectar; shake 1 minute.
Place 1 maraschino cherry in bottom of martini glass.
Strain mixture from shaker into glass.
Sprinkle with cinnamon and nutmeg.
Garnish side of glass with fresh pear slice.
Put the vodka, lime juice and ice into a shaker.
Shake.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Add a squeeze of lime juice and top with cayenne pepper.
Garnish with a lime slice.

data.title: Mini Mule Shot
data.description: A mini Moscow Mule.

list.step: Add vodka, ginger beer and lime juice into a shaker.
Stir gently.
Serve between 4 shot glasses or mini copper mugs.
Garnish with 1/4 lime slice.

data.title: Grasshopper Shot
data.description: The Grasshopper Shot is a green shot made from vodka, green creme de menthe, white creme de cacao and light cream, and served in a chilled shot glass.

list.step: Put all ingredients with ice in a cocktail shaker.
Shake well.
Strain into a chilled shot glass.
Garnish with fresh mint and serve with chocolate mints.

data.title: Blood Orange 100
data.description: The Blood Orange 100 is made from vodka, blood orange liqueur and lemon juice, and served in a chilled cocktail glass.

list.step: Shake the vodka, blood orange liqueur and lemon juice with ice in a cocktail shaker.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish with a slice of blood orange.

data.title: Dirty Gold Shot
data.description: The Dirty Gold Shot is made from vodka and olive juice, and served in a chilled shot glass.

list.step: Shake the vodka and olive juice with ice in a cocktail shaker.
Strain into a chilled shot glass.

data.title: Ginza Mary
data.description: The Ginza Mary is a somewhat Japanese variation of the classic Bloody Mary cocktail. Made from vodka, sake, tomato juice, lemon juice, Tabasco sauce, black pepper and soy sauce, and served over ice in a rocks glass.

list.step: Stir all ingredients with ice in a mixing glass.
Strain into a rocks glass full of ice.
Garnish with lemon slice.
Put the kiwi in a Boston shaker and mash it.
Add the sake, vodka, sugar syrup and shake with ice.
Pour into an old-fashioned glass or glass goblet.
Add in 1 splash of soda.
Garnish with a fresh mint leaf.

data.title: Fantastic Lake
data.description: A sake cocktail with an interesting flavour.

list.step: Add all ingredients (except laraha liqueur & tonic water) into a cocktail shaker.
Shake gently.
Strain into a glass goblet or collins glass.
Fill with tonic water.
Add the laraha liqueur.
Add a muddler.
Garnish with orange slice.

data.title: Melting Snow
data.description: A pretty sake sour.

list.step: Wet rim of old-fashioned glass and dip in salt.
Add sake, liqueur, lemon juice and ice into a cocktail shaker.
Shake gently.
Strain into a salt rimmed old-fashioned glass.
Add the grenadine.
Build in a salt rimmed old-fashioned glass.
Fill with ice.
Add all the ingredients.
Mix.
Garnish with grapefruit peel.

data.title: Lotus Blossom Martini
data.description: A perfect combination of pear-flavored vodka and sake, the Lotus Blossom is one flavour-filled Martini that is both complex and delicate. This recipe includes muddling lychee nuts, sugar, and lime, making it slightly more time consuming but worth every sip in the end.

list.step: In the bottom of a shaker place the lychee nuts, simple syrup and lime wedge.
Muddle gently.
Add ice, sake and vodka.
Shake vigorously until the outside of the shaker is frosted and beaded with sweat.
Strain into a cocktail glass.
Garnish with a sliced pear.
In a cocktail shaker, mix all ingredients and shake gently with ice.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish with a lime wedge.
Build in a sugar rimmed old-fashioned glass and fill with ice (large ice cubes are better).
Add all the ingredients and mix with a bar spoon.
Garnish with a lime wedge.

data.title: Autumn Moon
data.description: It's a simple, sweet twist on something approaches a Cosmopolitan -- though the name may say 'winter', the scarlet appearance of the drink and it's sweet, crisp taste reminds us more of the early days of spring.

list.step: Put all ingredients into a cocktail shaker and mix gently with ice.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish with a lime wedge.

data.title: Sake Bomb
data.description:
The Sake Bomb or Sake Bomber is a beer cocktail made by pouring sake into a shot glass and dropping it into a glass of beer.

Sometimes two chopsticks are placed parallel on top of the glass of beer, and the shot glass is carefully balanced between them. The drinker slams the table with their fists, causing the sake to fall into the beer. It should be drunk immediately, and works best with warm sake.

list.step: Fill a Collins glass with the beer.
Pour the sake into a shot glass.
Place 2 chopsticks on top of the glass and balance the shot glass on the chopsticks.
While doing the "sake chant" the guest beats on table until shot glass falls into the beer glass.

data.title: Saketini
data.description: In the Saketini, the sake acts like the vermouth of a classic Martini and adds a different nuance to the drink that only the "rice wine" can contribute.

list.step: Pour the ingredients into a mixing glass filled with ice.
Stir well.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish with a olives on a cocktail stick.

data.title: Bramble
data.description:
The Bramble is a blackberry-based cocktail that’s rather simple to make and is nicely balanced in its sweet and sour tones. The cocktail is on its way to modern classic status, if it hasn’t already reached it, frequenting more bars than Ernest Hemingway and Oliver Reed combined.

This is a drink best reserved for the end of summer, when that big yellow ball hangs lower in the sky and blackberries are readily available to be plucked from the bush and dolloped into your glass. However, with a few nifty substitutions, it can be transformed into a drink to match the Autumnal season.

list.step: Add the gin, lemon and sugar syrup to a shaker.
Shake well.
Strain into an ice-filled rocks glass.
Trickle the crème liqueur over the top, creating the ‘bramble’ type effect.
Garnish with blackberries.

data.title: Gin & Jam
data.description:
Though Gin & Jam may sound like a night put on for retired rockers in a village hall, in actual fact it’s a ludicrously simple, super-sweet cocktail that can – more of less – be rustled up from kitchen staples.

Bridesmaid pink, with a tart slither of citrus running through it, this is a cocktail designed with decadence in mind. The best thing about it is its adaptability; you can use strawberry jam in summer, blackberry in autumn and cranberry in winter. Our favourite preserve, though, and one that fills the mouth with a confectioners dusting of candied fruit, is raspberry.

list.step: Add the all of the ingredients into a cocktail shaker with ice.
Shake hard, the jam can put up a fight.
Strain into a cocktail glass filled with crushed ice.
Garnish with blackberries.

data.title: Gin Rickey
data.description: The Gin Rickey is a tall, uncomplicated drink with a good sweet and sour balance and a really refreshing hit. It’s the Gimlet’s elegant cousin, heading towards the “Southside” branch of the cocktail family, topped up with sugar syrup and tonic water. This is a cooling cocktail, a grown ups version of an ice lolly on a hot day.

list.step: Add the gin, juice and sugar syrup to a cocktail mixer with ice.
Shake.
Strain into a Collins glass.
Top up with sparkling water.
Garnish with a lime wedge.

data.title: Gin Gin Mule
data.description:
The Gin-Gin Mule is a long, tall and deliciously cooling cocktail whose green tint belies its fiery ginger DNA. Though a recent addition in the long history of ginger related cocktails, this is surely on its way to classic status, spreading out slowly from its New York birthplace to bars across the world.

The Gin-Gin Mule is best imbibed from an icey glass on a boiling hot day, proving perfectly that sometimes, just sometimes, you can fight fire with fire.

list.step: Muddle the mint leaves and syrup at the bottom of a shaker.
Pour in the gin and half a cup of ice.
Shake until cold.
Add in the ginger beer and stir, gently (if fizzy).
Fill a Collins glass with ice.
Pour in the cocktail and garnish couple of sprigs of mint.
Add the lime wedge to garnish.

data.title: Hanky Panky
data.description:
The Hanky Panky is a sweet Martini with bitter undertones. The cocktail was created by bonafide bartending legend Ada ‘Coley’ Coleman, who got in on the girl power action long before any crop-top wearing pop power combinations did, by becoming the first (and only to date) female head bartender at the Savoy.

This is an elegant drink made for sophisticated drinkers whose classy behaviour will falter by the time they hit the dregs; then it’s dancing on the table time.

list.step: Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.
Stir.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish with an orange twist.

data.title: Southside Royale
data.description: Turn the Southside (the green wonder) into a Royale. This is without doubt a cocktail for summer, so next time the sun drenched skies force you into the paddling pool – take one of these in with you for good measure.

list.step: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with plenty of ice.
Fine strain into a chilled Martini glass.
Top with Champagne.

data.title: Southside Fizz
data.description: Jazz up the Southside (the green wonder) with some fizz.

list.step: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with plenty of ice.
Fine strain into a chilled Martini glass.
Top with soda water.

data.title: Southside
data.description: Southside is a translucent, green wonder cocktail that has long languished in the shadows of its hyperactive cousin, the Mojito.

list.step: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with plenty of ice.
Shake.
Fine strain into a chilled Martini glass.

data.title: Earl Grey Martini
data.description: This delicious twist on a martini is made with just three ingredients and takes minutes to make. The bergamot oil in the Earl Grey gives a lovely citrus hit.

list.step: Put the Earl Grey tea in a large jug.
Pour the gin over and stir with a long-handled spoon for about 45 secs.
Strain the gin through a tea strainer over a funnel back into the bottle.
Rinse out the jug and, using a coffee filter or some muslin inside the funnel, strain the gin a second time to remove all the particles.
To serve, shake or stir over ice.

data.title: Dark & Stormy Coffee
data.description: Are you a die-hard fan of a dark and stormy? Twist up a classic cocktail with a dash of freshly brewed espresso to pair with traditional ginger beer.

list.step: Fill a highball glass with ice.
Pour in the rum and tequila.
Stir.
Top with ginger beer.
Slowly pour in the espresso.

data.title: Eastern Breeze
data.description: Christmas is hectic enough, so this vibrant vegan cocktail couldn’t be simpler to make and is perfect for batch making quickly for a large group.

list.step: Fill six highball or big wine glasses with ice.
Divide vodka, mint leaves, pomegranate seeds and apple juice between them.
Stir to muddle.

data.title: Coco Fizz
data.description: Spruce up the classic coconut and rum combination with a dash of Prosecco and a squeeze of lime for a festive cocktail you can shake up in seconds

list.step: Put the coconut rum, coconut water and lime juice into a cocktail shaker with ice.
Shake until the outside of the shaker is icy-cold to the touch.
Strain into a chilled coupe glass.
Top with the Prosecco.

data.title: Inside Job
data.description: Nobody will suspect a thing if you just sit quietly and enjoy this sophisticated bourbon cocktail.

list.step: Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.
Stir.
Strain into an Old Fashioned glass filled with fresh ice.
Garnish with a cherry and an orange slice.

data.title: Proven Perfect
data.description: Port, Fernet Branca and cardamom-infused bitter liqueur take a bourbon cocktail to uncharted territory.

list.step: Add port, oolong and rooibos tea to a glass container
Steep for 18 minutes.
Filter out tea.
Add cardamom pods and Amèr Nouvelle to a glass container.
Steep for 20-25 minutes.
Filter out cardamom pods.
Add all ingredients, except the lemon peel, to a mixing glass and fill with ice.
Stir.
Strain into a chilled cocktail or coupe glass.
Express lemon oils over cocktail.
Place peel on side of glass.
Garnish with a maraschino cherry.
Using an atomiser, spritz several squeezes of absinthe into a double rocks glass, thoroughly coating the interior.
Shake out the excess.
Add remaining ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.
Stir vigorously.
Strain into the double rocks glass.
Fill with cubed ice.
Garnish with a dried orange slice.

data.title: The Fox Mulder
data.description: This X-Files–inspired cocktail is a classic Whisky Sour with a pineapple twist. A Green Chartreuse float gives the drink an ethereal appearance, but the high-proof, medicinal bite keeps it grounded.

list.step: Add all ingredients except the Green Chartreuse to a shaker filled with ice.
Shake.
Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice.
Top with a float of Green Chartreuse.

data.title: Prime Directive
data.description: It’s the guiding principle for all members of Star Trek’s Starfleet: Don’t mess with other civilisations and sully up their worlds. Which is a pretty good rule to follow for drinks, too. Keep things light and herby with this gin cocktail.

list.step: Add all ingredients into a shaker.
Stir.
Strain into a chilled coupe.
Garnish with a lemon twist.

data.title: Old Cuban
data.description: Bartender Audrey Saunders is best known for her work at Soho’s Pegu Club, where her drink credits include this Mojito-meets–French 75 classic.

list.step: Muddle the lime juice, syrup and mint in a mixing glass.
Add the rum, bitters and ice and shake.
Double-strain into a coupe glass.
Top with Champagne.

data.title: Coral Coolers
data.description: This low-calorie fruit punch will bring the sounds of the beach into your home.

list.step: Mix pineapple juice, soda pop and cherry juice; pour into ice-filled glasses.
Garnish each with maraschino cherry.

data.title: Strawberry Sangría
data.description: Strawberry puree, fruit juice and wine come together in this refreshing Sangria beverage.

list.step: To make strawberry puree, place strainer over medium bowl; pour strawberries and syrup into strainer. Press mixture with back of spoon through strainer to remove seeds; discard seeds.
In a pitcher, mix strawberry puree, fruit juice concentrate and wine.
Just before serving, stir in carbonated beverage.
Serve in wine glasses over ice.
Garnish each serving with strawberry half.

data.title: White Wine Sangria
data.description: Drop-in guests? No problem! 10 minutes is all it takes to prepare this celebratory drink.

list.step: In pitcher, stir sugar, orange liqueur and vodka until sugar is dissolved.
In another pitcher, pour half of vodka mixture. Divide fruits and wine evenly between pitchers.
Divide fruits and wine evenly between pitchers.
Refrigerate until serving.
Just before serving, pour half of club soda into each pitcher.
Stir gently to mix.
Serve over ice, if desired.

data.title: Sparkling Citrus Punch
data.description: Easy to make, this recipe makes plenty--enough to quench the thirst of a large gathering of friends and family!

list.ingredient: frozen tangerine or orange juice concentrate

list.step: Mix all ingredients in punch bowl.
Serve over ice.

data.title: Firecracker Punch
data.description: Treat your guests with this citrusy punch.

list.step: In a saucepan, cook the cinnamon sweet and 250ml of the water over medium-high heat, stirring frequently, until candies are melted.
Remove from heat.
Cool completely, about 30 minutes.
In large punch bowl, stir candy mixture, remaining 700ml water, the lemonade and orange juice concentrates until well mixed.
Refrigerate until ready to serve.
Just before serving, gently stir in ginger ale.
Garnish with orange slices.

data.title: Sugar Cookie Martini
data.description: We captured the sweet taste of sugar cookies in our Sugar Cookie Martini made with chocolate and Irish cream liqueurs, vodka, whole milk and butterscotch syrup. Rim the glass with sprinkles for a festive touch.

list.step: In cocktail shaker, add all ingredients except sprinkles.
Shake until cold.
Dip rim of martini glass into water then into sprinkles.
Pour martini into glass.
Top with more sprinkles.

data.title: Modern Old-Fashioned
data.description: This modern take on an old-fashioned cocktail infuses the flavours of peach, citrus and maple syrup into the classic bourbon drink. Finish it off with a single, large ice cube to give it a modern twist that’s perfect for a dimly-lit bar or just kicking back on the sofa.

list.ingredient: extra-large ice cube or standard ice cubes

list.step: Add extra-large ice cube to lowball or rocks glass.
Muddle orange slice, lemon slice, chopped peach and maple syrup in cocktail shaker until fruit is broken up.
Add standard ice cubes, bourbon and bitters to shaker.
Shake.
Strain into glass.
Garnish with peach slice.

data.title: Royal Blue
data.description: This gem of a cocktail has a hint of citrus flavour, while also providing a jewel-inspired colour tone.

list.step: Moisten rim of chilled martini glass with lime wedge.
Sprinkle sugar onto small plate, and dip moistened rim into the sugar to coat lightly.
Fill cocktail shaker with ice.
Add cranberry juice, vodka, curacao and lime juice.
Cover and shake.
Strain into martini glass.

data.title: Black Widow Martini
data.description: Do you dare to try this devilishly spirited cocktail? Dark rum and chocolate liqueur, plus a bit of black food colouring, combine for a darkly delicious drink.

list.step: In small bowl, add brown sugar and 1 drop black food colouring.
Mix with fork until all sugar is black.
Wet rim of martini glass with water.
Dip rim into sugar.
Add rum, liqueur, ice and 1 or 2 drops black food colouring to a martini shaker.
Shake.
Strain martini into glass.

data.title: Pornstar Martini
data.description: It's an absolute modern classic which was invented by Douglas Ankrah of LAB bar and has since been adopted by many bars across the globe. The sweet vanilla vodka flavours are balanced by the sharpness of the passionfruit and is complemented by a shot of Prosecco or Champagne on the side.

list.notes: Prosecco can be used as an alternative

list.step: Add all of the ingredients excluding the Champagne into a cocktail shaker filled with ice.
Shake until cool to the touch.
Strain into a glass.
Garnish with half a passionfruit.
Add Champagne to a shot glass and serve as a chaser in between sips.

data.title: Kumquat Martini
data.description: Get in the cheer with this sipping cocktail. It's a cross between a mint julep and a classic martini.

list.step: In cocktail shaker, muddle kumquat slices and mint leaves with muddler or back of wooden spoon.
Add simple syrup, ice and vodka.
Cover; shake until thoroughly chilled.
Pour into chilled martini glass, straining out ice, kumquats and mint.
Garnish with additional kumquat slices and mint leaves, if desired.

data.title: Pomegranate Martini
data.description: Pomegranate martinis are a perfect cocktail to serve during the holiday season. The fresh pomegranate juice in this martini recipe makes a sweeter vodka cocktail everyone will love.

list.step: Fill martini shaker half full with ice.
Add all ingredients except pomegranate seeds and lime slices.
Cover and shake.
Pour into a martini glass. Pour through a strainer to keep the ice out of the glass.
Garnish with lime slice, and pomegranate seeds.

data.title: Skinny Clementine Martini
data.description: Add some clever sparkle to your next party. Enjoy these natural, light martinis made with fresh juice, high-quality liquor, and a splash of club soda. Lower calorie cocktails never tasted, or looked, so sweet.

list.notes: alternatively you can use orange liqueur

list.step: In cocktail shaker filled with ice, add gin, liqueur and juices.
Cover and shake until well mixed.
Strain into martini glass.
Top off with club soda.
Garnish with clementine slice and grapefruit peel.
Add ice, moonshines and cranberry juice to glass.
Stir.
Garnish with cinnamon stick.
Add ice and all ingredients to glass.
Stir well.
Garnish with lemon wedge.
Pour a tall glass of stout.
Top with moonshine.
Add ice, moonshine and tea into a glass.
Stir.
Garnish with lemon wedge.

data.title: Apple Ginger

Stir well.
Garnish with apple slice.

list.notes: alternatively you can use a wheat beer

list.step: Pour pint of beer.
Top with shot of moonshine
Garnish with apple slice.

data.title: American Mule
data.description: This is an American spin on a classic Russian drink.

list.step: Build the ingredients up in a copper mug filled with ice.
Stir well.
Garnish with mint and lime.

data.title: Paper Plane
data.description: The Paper Plane is pleasantly easy to remember thanks to its equal parts.

list.step: Add all ingredients to a shaker filled with ice.
Shake.
Strain into a coupe glass.

data.title: Bourbon Manhattan
data.description: You don’t need to be in the five boroughs to enjoy this sophisticated tipple.

list.step: Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.
Stir.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish with a cherry.

data.title: Rosemary Paloma
data.description: A simple rosemary syrup gives the classic grapefruit Paloma a hint of a little something special.

list.step: Combine fresh rosemary leaves and water in a pot, and bring to a boil.
Add sugar and stir constantly until fully dissolved.
Strain rosemary leaves and let syrup cool to room temperature before using.
Do not refrigerate to quicken cooling time, as sugar may crystallise from cooling too quickly.
Once cool, use immediately or store refrigerated in an airtight container for up to 2 weeks.
Add the tequila, syrup and juice in a shaker with ice and shake.
Shake.
Strain into a Collins glass.
Fill the glass to the top with ice, and top with grapefruit soda.
Garnish with a rosemary sprig.

data.title: Pisco Sour
data.description: Both Chile and Peru claim the classic Pisco Sour as their own.

Shake vigorously.
Strain into a highball glass or Champagne flute.
Garnish with a lime wheel.
Add 3 gentle drops of Angostura Bitters which will settle in the foam of the cocktail.
Using a straw, swirl the bitters into a simple design.

data.title: Prospector
data.description: This bourbon-and-amaro drink pairs well with holiday spices and can be served warmed up or chilled.

list.step: Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.
Stir for 15 seconds.
Strain into a coupe glass.
Express the oils of the lemon twist over the drink, and gently drop the twist into the cocktail.

data.title: Irish Maid
data.description: Made with cucumber, elderflower and whisky, this is a sour cocktail you can’t help but get sweet on.

list.step: In a shaker, muddle the cucumber slices.
Add remaining ingredients and fill shaker with ice.
Shake vigorously, and fine-strain into a chilled rocks glass filled with ice.
Garnish with a cucumber slice.

data.title: Bourbon Ricky
data.description: Though its cousin the Gin Rickey is more common today, this classic cocktail recipe can also be made with bourbon.

list.step: Fill a highball glass with cracked ice.
Squeeze the lime half into the glass and drop it in.
Add the bourbon and fill with club soda.
Stir briefly to combine.

data.title: White Lady
data.description: She may look delicate, but this is one strong woman.

list.step: Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.
Shake.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

data.title: Last Word
data.description: This complex, herbal cocktail will win any argument.

list.step: Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice.
Shake.
Double-strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

data.title: Clove Club
data.description: This pre-Prohibition classic is one of Philadelphia’s contributions to mixological history.

list.notes: If you don't have raspberry syrup, you can muddle together 3 or 4 fresh raspberries and 10ml simple syrup instead.

Shake.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish with three speared raspberries.

data.title: Vesper
data.description: Pay tribute to 007 by mixing up his signature Vesper cocktail. The drink first appeared in Ian Fleming’s 1953 novel Casino Royale when Bond asked for “Three measures of Gordon’s, one of vodka, half a measure of Kina Lillet. Shake it very well until it’s ice-cold, then add a large thin slice of lemon peel. Got it?”

list.step: Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.
Stir.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Twist a slice of lemon peel over the drink, rub along the rim of the glass and drop it in.

data.title: Gibson
data.description: The Martini’s savory second cousin, the Gibson uses a pickled cocktail onion in place of the typical briny olive to add an umami undertone to the classic cocktail. The Gibson is believed to have been created by San Francisco businessman Walter D.K. Gibson in the late 1800s, who thought that eating onions prevented colds, hence the addition of the mini allium.

list.notes: vodka can be used as a replacement

list.step: Add both ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.
Stir.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish with a whole cocktail onion.

data.title: Dry Martini
data.description: The Dry Martini is a classic cocktail that, like a tailored suit, is timeless. Although the original of the tipple is unclear, the Dry Martini has maintained a place in cocktail history due to being easy to use and endlessly sophisticated. Elegant for the fancy and boozy for the heavy-handed, this potation is truly the everyman’s cocktail.

list.step: Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.
Stir until very cold and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish with an olive.

data.title: Marguerite
data.description: The typical recipes of the 20’s & 30’s that can be found elsewhere reflect a shift from Sweet to Dry Vermouth, larger doses of gin in the ratio and less other additions such as liqueurs and sugar. One cocktail stands out in particular in highlighting all these facts and is in the landmark Savoy Cocktail Book, the Marguerite.

list.step: Add all the ingredients to a mixing glass and fill with ice.
Stir.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish with a orange twist.
Pour the gin, vermouth and bitters into a mixing glass with ice cubes.
Stir well.
Strain into chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish with the grapefruit zest after first twisting over the glass to spray the oils over the drink.

data.title: Watercress & Basil Gin Smash
data.description:
Whereas a 'Julep' is made from mint, a 'Smash' is generally accepted as a muddled-herb cocktail mixed with a base spirit, sweetener and some kind of citrus (or other acidic juice component).

In this case we're using both Basil and Watercress as an adaptation of Jörg Meyer's “gin pesto” invented at the bar Le Lion in Hamburg back in 2008.

The pesto-like quality of the basil sounds like an odd companion to gin, but the peppery spice and herbaceous notes in our Twisted Nose gin really make this work, so give it a try - it will certainly be a talking point and we think you will be pleasantly surprised.

list.step: Muddle the watercress and basil in the base of a cocktail shaker and leave for 5-10 minutes.
Add the ice, gin, lemon juice and sugar syrup and shake for one minute.
Double-strain into an chilled coupe glass
Garnish with watercress and basil leaf.

data.title: Kentucky mule
data.description:
Who says you can’t have your copper mug and your bourbon, too? This twist on the Moscow Mule pairs American whiskey and ginger beer for a refreshing summer cocktail.

Best served in a cooper Moscow Mule mug, alternatively you can use a Highball glass.

list.step: Add the bourbon and lime juice to a mug or glass.
Fill the with ice and top with ginger beer.
Add mint sprig for garnish.

data.title: Whisky Sour
data.description: The Whisky Sour is one classic cocktail that won’t make you sour.

list.step: Add all the ingredients to a shaker filled with ice.
Shake well.
Strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.
Garnish with a cherry and lemon wedge.

data.title: Sake Champagne Mojito
data.description: This is an absolutely smooth and delicious cocktail. It is the perfect summer cocktail and a guaranteed hit when entertaining!

list.step: Tear the mint leaves off the stem.
In a large pitcher, use the back of a wooden spoon to muddle the mint leaves, stevia, and lime juice.
Add the entire bottle of Sake and entire bottle of Champagne.
Stir the mixture.
Serve over lots of ice in rocks glasses or mason jars.

data.title: Rum and Cola
data.description: This is a great party drink, being quick and uncomplicated to make, and suitable for most palates. Make it your main mix when you have a lot of guests to keep happy.

list.step: Fill a highball glass with ice.
Add rum and cola.
Garnish with lime wedge.

data.title: Tequila, Lime and Soda
data.description: A fresh drink that makes for easy sipping. The sharp citrus flavours provide a simple, refreshing taste, making it a good choice for hot summer nights.

list.step: Drop a lime wedge into the bottom of a glass and top with ice.
Add tequila.
Top with soda and an additional lime wedge.

data.title: Mint Julep
data.description: The classic Mint Julep is a drink that’s built for sweltering southern summers – the metal mug and crushed ice keep it extra frosty, even in high temperatures, while the combination of mint and bourbon gives it a refreshing sweetness.

data.title: Apple and Soda
data.description: This clear golden-coloured blend of whisky, apple juice and sparkling soda is a refreshing way to serve whisky in the summer. It’s an easy drink to make, too, so is ideal if you’re having friends over for the evening. The smooth, creamy base of Johnnie Walker contrasts well with the sweet and tangy apple juice, and a spritz of soda gives it a lively fizz.

list.step: Pour the whisky into an ice-filled Collins glass.
Add the clear apple juice and top with soda.
Garnish with a thin slice of apple.

data.title: Bourbon, Lemon and Tonic
data.description: There’s nothing quite as refreshing as a sparkling glass of lemonade, and this grown-up version is no exception. The sharpness of the lemon combined with the sweet base of bourbon and the bitter edge of the tonic give this drink a savoury lemon sherbet taste that’s perfect for humid summer evenings.

list.step: Fill a Collins glass with ice.
Add the bourbon and tonic water.
Coat the rim of the glass with the juice from one of the lemon wedges, and squeeze the remaining juice into the glass.
Garnish with the other lemon wedge.

data.title: Daiquiri
data.description: Those whose only experiences of the Daiquiri are garish chain restaurant offerings will find this classic recipe a far cry from the sugary drink they’re used to. Keeping any meddling to a minimum is key: this is a simple balance of a strong rum base, sweet sugar syrup and sour lime, with each flavour working in harmony. Serve it when you want to bring sunny beaches to mind – lazy summer gatherings with friends are the perfect excuse.

list.step: Fill a shaker with rum, fresh lime juice, sugar syrup and ice.
Shake well.
Strain the contents into a coupe.
Garnish with a lime twist (if desired).

data.title: Batanga
data.description: Simple cola drinks don’t start and end with a Cuba Libre – if you’re looking for a drier mix, then the tequila-based Batanga should fit the bill. With just three ingredients, and no adventurous techniques to get to grips with, it’s as easy as pouring and serving, which makes it a good choice if you have a lot of thirsty guests to cater to.

list.step: Fill a highball glass with ice cubes.
Squeeze the juice from a lime wedge into the glass, and rub around the rim to coat with any remaining juice.
Pour in the tequila and cola.
Garnish with a second wedge of lime.

data.title: Gin Cobbler
data.description: Because of the gin’s intensity, we suggest serving it in a cobbler as it doesn’t require much else to really shine. Cobblers are an old form of mixed drink that consists of a base spirit, (the most popular historically being sherry), with sugar and fresh fruit. They date from at least the 1830’s, and made using two items very new to people of that time – ice, and straws. The Sherry Cobbler was one of the most popular libations during the last half of the 19thCentury.

list.step: Put all ingredients into a shaker.
Shake hard with ice.
Pour into a glass.
Fill with crushed ice.
Garnish with fresh berries.
Add a straw.

data.title: Reverse Martinez
data.description:
The Martinez is one of our all-time favourite classic gin cocktails. This is a version inspired by the serve at Employees Only in NYC and lightens up the classic Martinez. The ratios are also inverted, making gin the dominant ingredient and changing the aroma of the cocktail considerably.

Flavour-wise, this cocktail fits somewhere between a traditional Gin Martini and its sweeter and richer predecessor, the Martinez.

list.step: Add the gin, dry vermouth, maraschino liqueur and absinthe bitters to a mixing glass.
Fill 2/3 with ice and stir until well chilled.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish with the lemon twist.

data.title: Darkside
data.description: The Darkside cocktail combines smooth and light elements with the sweetness of elderflower. While you can garnish the drink with a brandied cherry, it can also be presented beautifully using a lime twist.

list.step: Add the gin, Sweet Vermouth and elderflower liqueur to a mixing glass.
Fill 2/3 full with ice and stir until well chilled.
Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.
Garnish with a brandied cherry.

data.title: Archangel
data.description:
A simple mix of muddled cucumber, gin, and Aperol might sound unexciting however, we can assure you that the combination is much, much tastier than the sum of its parts.

The Archangel comes from Michael McIlroy and Richard Boccato from New York’s Milk & Honey. Refreshing and easy to make, it’s easy to see why this cocktail appeals to bartenders and customers alike.

list.step: Add the cucumber slices to the bottom of a mixing glass.
Muddle them to break up, but do not pulverize completely.
Add Gin and Aperol to mixing glass then fill 2/3 with ice.

Strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

data.title: Frozen Caipirinha
data.description: Cool down with this frozen spin on the classic Brazilian Caipirinha. The secret is squeezing as much lime into the sugar as you can.

list.step: Cut each of the lime halves into four chunks.
Put in a large mortar with the sugar and squish well with a pestle to break them down – they will release their juices, leaving you with a sweet lime syrup.
Remove the lime peel, squeeze to release the last bits of juice, then discard.
Transfer the lime syrup to a small plastic container and freeze for at least 4 hrs, ideally overnight.
When you’re ready to make the cocktail, put the ice in a blender suitable for crushing ice, then add the frozen syrup and cachaça.
Blend at a high speed until smooth and thick.
Transfer to cocktail glasses or tumblers and serve immediately.

Pour the elderflower cordial, elderflower liqueur, gin and a large handful of ice cubes into a large jug.

Top with the soda and add a few more ice cubes and the floral ones too.
Serve immediately.

The drink was first concocted at the Old Absinthe House bar in 1874 by Cayetano Ferrer, and was served to famous customers such as Oscar Wilde, Mark Twain, and General Robert E. Lee, just to name a few.

Pour into a chimney glass.
Add ice to fill.
Garnish with a mint sprig.
Add ice, gin, bourbon and absinthe to shaker.
Shake for 10-15 seconds.
Strain into a collins glass with ice.
Garnish with a lime wedge on the side of the glass.

data.description: Champion drinker Ernest Hemingway claimed to have invented the Death in the Afternoon, a risky pairing of absinthe and Champagne, himself. His exact instructions suggested adding iced Champagne to a jigger of absinthe until it attained “the proper opalescent milkiness,” then proceeding to drink three to five of the cocktails in one sitting.

If you’re looking for an easy-to-prepare group drink, this rich, buttery, caramel-colour punch is a simple option that works well on a frosty winter's evening.

list.ingredient: Any of the following whole spices: cinnamon; nutmeg; ginger; clove; and cardamom

Pour into a punch bowl.

data.title: Candy Cane Cocktail
data.description: The beauty of vodka is that it can be infused with almost anything, from sweet vanilla to fiery chilli. This doesn't need to be left to the pros, either, as anyone who has spent time on Pinterest in the run-up to the festive season will have noticed, you can create a multitude of infused flavours at home and try your hand at some inventive cocktails.

list.ingredient: clear Crème de Cacao (plus a little for the rim)

list.step: Pour the vodka into a lidded jar.
Split the vanilla pod lengthways with a sharp knife and add to the vodka.
Break or crush the candy canes (crush with a rolling pin or use a food processor).
Add the crushed candy canes to the jar with the vanilla pod and vodka.
If required, add a splash of cherry brandy for colour.
Seal and leave in a cool, dark place for around four days (longer, if possible), shaking occasionally.
When ready, strain to remove the vanilla pod and sediment.
Place candy cane in a food processor and blend until it’s the consistency of granulated sugar (if you don't have a food processor, crush the candy canes using a rolling pin, as above).
Apply Crème de Cacao to the outer rim of a Martini glass or coupe.
Coat the rim with the crushed candy cane.
Pour the candy cane vodka, Crème de Cacao and Angostura bitters into a shaker with ice.
Shake and strain into a Martini glass or coupe (use a sieve to catch any remaining sediment).

Add the whisky and stir once more.

Add vodka, lemon juice and vanilla syrup to an ice-filled cocktail shaker.
Shake until chilled.
Strain through a fine mesh strainer into the chilled glass.
Top with soda water and garnish with a dark grape.

data.title: Bergamot mojito
data.description: Perfumed bergamot zest and juice are combined with rum, mint, lime and sugar in a twist on the standard mojito - serve at a dinner party as guests arrive.

list.step: Mix the sugar with 1 litre of water in a medium saucepan. Bring to the boil, then cool to room temperature.

Blend the mint, lime juice and bergamot zest and juice in a food processor, then add the cooled syrup and blend until combined. Pour into a plastic container and freeze, stirring with a fork every 30 mins until frozen.
To serve, scoop the granita into chilled glasses and pour the rum over.
